Award.AwardTitle: Catalytic Diene-Diol Benzannulation for Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbon Construction
Award.AbstractNarration:
The Chemical Synthesis Program of the NSF Chemistry Division supports the research of Professor Michael J. Krische in the Department of Chemistry at the University of Texas at Austin. Professor Krische and his students are developing novel, green catalytic methods for the construction of PAH (polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbon) - materials that are used broadly in molecular electronics. Professor Krische's method involves the byproduct-free coupling of inexpensive, abundant petrochemical feedstocks (dienes) with a renewable feedstock (diols). PAH materials are formed upon dehydration of the reaction products, meaning water is the only chemical byproduct. This project lies at the interface of organic, organometallic and materials chemistry and provides a suitable forum for the education of undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral scientists. With the growing Hispanic demographic in Texas, Professor Krische's group has played a strong role in the education and training of students from groups historically underrepresented in science. Outreach activities include an annual research symposia sponsored by the Center for Green Chemistry and Catalysis led by Professor Krische, which features lectures by leading chemists in the field of catalysis, as well as poster sessions hosting undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral scientists.

The Krische laboratory is pioneering a broad, new class of catalytic carbon-carbon (C-C) bond formations that merge the characteristics of catalytic hydrogenation and carbonyl addition, representing the first "C-C bond forming hydrogenations" beyond hydroformylation. This new pattern of reactivity is the basis of a ruthenium(0) catalyzed diene-diol [4+2] cycloaddition. This byproduct-free transformation is being used to advance new benzannulation technology for the construction of Polycyclic Aromatic Hydrocarbons (PAHs). Acenes, polyphenylenes, fluoranthenes and carbon nano-allotropes - there is great interest in such PAH materials in the field of molecular electronics. However, since the advent of biaryl cross-coupling technology, the field of PAH construction has remained largely unchanged. Just as biaryl cross-coupling technology revolutionized PAH construction, diene-diol benzannulation may unlock new PAH chemical space, broadly impacting research across the carbon nano-allotrope and molecular device communities. The educational plan includes annual research symposia sponsored by the Center for Green Chemistry and Catalysis led by Professor Krische, which features lectures by leading chemists in the field of catalysis, as well as poster sessions hosting undergraduate, graduate and postdoctoral scientists.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes (NSF-CH-1565688): “Catalytic Diene-Diol Benzannulation for PAH Construction”

 

Background and Scientific Impacts: C-C Bond formation is fundamental to the endeavor of chemical synthesis. Since the advent of the Grignard reaction (1900), stoichiometric organometallic reagents have continuously played a dominant role in C-C bond formation, especially carbonyl addition. Catalytic hydrogenation, discovered by Paul Sabatier (1897), has found far broader use in industry due to it’s atom-efficiency and scalability. Under the aegis of NSF support, Professor Krische has discovered and developed a family of C-C bond forming processes wherein catalytic hydrogenation or transfer hydrogenation is used to generate transient organometallics that may be exploited in diverse asymmetric carbonyl additions, enabling C-C coupling beyond the use of stoichiometric organometallic reagents. Krische’s catalytic processes combine hydrogenation and carbonyl addition. Based on this new reactivity pattern, unique diol-mediated cycloadditions were developed. Under the aegis of NSF support, this cycloaddition methodology was used to advance new benzannulation strategies for the construction of polycyclic aromatic hydrocarbons (PAH). Although PAH’s and carbon nano-allotropes are of great interest in molecular electronics, the field of PAH construction has remained largely unchanged since the advent of biaryl cross-coupling technology. Just as cross-coupling transformed PAH construction, our new benzannulation technology is unlocking new volumes of PAH chemical space, fueling diverse research beyond our own laboratory. The innovation associated with our work has been widely recognized, most recently through our receipt of the 2020 ACS Award for Creativity in Synthetic Organic Chemistry.

 

The work accomplished during the prior funding period has been presented in 47 invited seminars at academic and industrial venues in the USA and abroad and has been recorded in the scientific literature, as illustrated by the following publications that appear in top tier chemistry journals.

 

  • ·         “Diols, α-Ketols and Diones as 22π Components in [2+2+2] Cycloadditions of 1,6-Diynes via Ruthenium(0) Catalyzed Transfer Hydrogenation,” Sato, H.; Bender, M.; Chen, W.; Krische, M. J. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2016, 138, 16244.

 

  • ·         “Helical Rod-Like Phenylene Cages via Ruthenium Catalyzed Diol-Diene Benzannulation: A Cord of Three Strands,” Sato, H.; Bender, J. A.; Roberts, S. T.; Krische, M. J. J. Am. Chem. Soc. 2018, 140, 2455.

 

  • ·         “Ruthenium(0) Catalyzed Cycloaddition of 1,2-Diols, Ketols or Diones via Alcohol-Mediated Hydrogen Transfer,” Sato, H.; Turnbull, B. W. H.; Fukaya, K.; Krische, M. J. Angew. Chem. Int. Ed. 2018, 57, 3012.

 

  • ·         “Alternating oligo(o,p-Phenylenes) via Ruthenium Catalyzed Diol-Diene Benzannulation: Orthogonality to Cross-Coupling Enables De Novo Nanographene and PAH Construction,” Kasun, Z. A.; Sato, H.; Nie, J.; Mori, Y.; Bender, J. A.; Roberts, S. T.; Krische, M. J. Chem. Sci. 2018, 9, 7866.

 

  • ·         “Triple Helical Ir(ppy)3 Phenylene Cage Prepared via Diol-Mediated Benzannulation: Synthesis, Resolution, Absolute Stereochemistry and Photophysical Properties,” Sato, H.; Blemker, M. A.; Hellinghausen, G.; Armstrong, D. W.; Nafie, J. W.; Roberts, S. T.; Krische, M. J. Chem. Eur. J. 2019, 25, 8719.

 

Broader Impacts: In addition to the research activities described above, another significant outcome of this work resides in the training of undergraduates, graduate students and postdoctoral research associates. Students involved in this project have participated in numerous training activities, including participation in regional/national American Chemical Society meetings. Additionally, the PI launched and continues to co-organize state-wide biennial symposia on green chemistry and catalysis called “TexSyn”. This event typically attracts >100 attendees and includes a poster session for graduate students and postdoctoral trainees. For example, Hiroki Sato (Graduate Student) received his doctoral degree and is now a JSPS postdoctoral fellow in the laboratory of Professor Ken Itami at Nagoya University. Timothy Patrick Montgomery (Graduate Student), received his doctoral degree and is now employed at Pfizer in San Diego, California). Dr. Laina Geary (Postdoc) began her independent career as a tenure-track assistant professor at the University of Nevada, Reno and was recently tenured. Dr. Ivan Volchkov (Postdoc) received a job in the process chemistry department at Boehringer-Ingelheim pharmaceuticals.

 

Women continue to be underrepresented in the sciences, especially in the field of synthetic chemistry for pharmaceutical and agrochemical research. To foster greater gender diversity, it is important that our female graduate student cohort in the UT Austin Department of Chemistry is exposed to successful role models. Consequently, I raised >$10K in funding to support a “Women in Synthesis and Catalysis” symposium at UT Austin. This event, which was scheduled for 04/19/2020, was postponed due to the COVID-19 quarantine and is rescheduled for 09/19/2020. It will feature 5 preeminent female chemists from the US and Canada. It is our goal that this will be the first of many biennial events.

 

  

 


Last Modified: 06/03/2020
Modified by: Michael J Krische
